Blending.Silent Prefix Clusters kn-, gn-.lessonName: Silent Prefix Clusters kn-, gn-, wr- ...
Blending.Silent Prefix Clusters kn-, gn-.lessonKey: Blending.Silent Prefix Clusters kn-, gn-, wr- ...
pages:
This lesson has some tricky words that start with 'silent' letters like kn-, gn-, and wr-.
It is incorrect to say that these letters are silent, because letters are built up into spellings and those spellings are not silent. The 'k' in 'knot' is not silent, but rather the 'kn' in 'knot' is pronounced 'n'. This idea is explored in the 'Phonics' course.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

pages:
Words that end with '-dge' or -'nge' have a silent-e at the end, but that 'e' does NOT change the sound of the previous vowel.
Compare the sounds on the word-pairs in the Stretch page. Often if there are two letters between the vowel and the silent-e, these words do not follow the a_e pattern.
Read across or down. Require clear pronunciation.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.
Read across or down. Require clear pronunciation.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

Bye-bye -e Rule: Drop the e (at the end of a base word) before adding a suffix that begins with a vowel.

Suffixes are endings (-ing, -ed) added to base/root words that show action.

A double vowel would be incorrect (bakeing).

These base words show action. Sometimes we call an action word a doing word or a verb.
Read across or down. Require clear pronunciation.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

This section of lessons introduces syllable division. The first syllable rule we will learn is:
VCCV: Divide between the two middle consonants.


1. Find the vowels.
2. Count the consonants between the vowels.
3. If there are two consonants, divide between them*
4. Read each syllable separately.
5. Read the entire word.

*when the two middle consonants form a digraph (ch, sh, ck, th), keep the consonants together and divide after the digraph (tick/et, chick/en, etc).
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

A contraction is a word or phrase that has been shortened by dropping one or more letters. In writing, an apostrophe is used to indicate the place of the missing letters.
  • I am = I’m
  • are not = aren’t
  • you will = you’ll
  • how did = how’d
  • where is = where’s
  • they have = they’ve
    • On the following practice tabs, read the contraction and identify the individual words that were combined to create the contraction.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

WHAT IS PHONICS?
We use about 40 sounds for speaking English. Since we only have 26 letters, we can't simply use a letter of the alphabet for each sound.
Here's a sound that you can't find in the alphabet: oy and it has two common spellings:
'Phonics' is about mapping sounds to spellings that represent those sounds.

Letters: There are 26 letters. Letters make spellings and spellings make sounds. We shouldn't say "this letter makes a sound", because only spellings make sounds.
Spellings: There are about 180 common spellings, and spellings make sounds. The simplest spellings have one letter like 'a' in a which makes the ah sound in 'cat'.
People get confused because the letter 'a' seems the same as the spelling a which makes the ah sound. But that doesn't work for the spelling oi which makes the oy in 'soil'.
Now can you explain why 'letters' and 'spellings' are not the same?

In this program we will show sounds like this: oi and spellings like this: oy and oi.
We simplify the colours when we show a word-drawing. You are familiar with word-drawings if you have taken the Blending program.

Here is the PURPOSE of the 'PHONICS' program:
There are only a few sounds.But probably more than you think.You must be able to recognize them.
Sounds have multiple spellings, and many common words have uncommon spellings. It is confusing, and we can't help that. The purpose of this program is to visit the sounds and build awareness of them.
Identify the SOUND and the SPELLING of the vowel in each word.
There are five spellings that have a trailing 'e', and we link the spelling together with a red bar. You have already mastered reading these spellings, .

It is NOT correct to say that 'e' is silent in 'gate' or 'note'. Nor is it correct to say that 'e' in the spelling a_e of 'gate' modifies the sound of the a. The correct way to think is that the spelling a makes the sound ah and the spelling a_e makes the sound ay.
For this program, let's pretend that there are NO silent letters in English. The 'k' in 'knife' is not silent, but rather the spelling kn makes the sound n. You will see that this approach simplifies English spelling and make it much more regular.
Identify the SOUND and the SPELLING of the vowel in each word.

What is a vowel?
The answer might surprise you. Before you turn to the next page, try to figure out how many vowels there are.
The five spellings a, e, i, o, u, and sometimes y?
The five short-vowel sounds ah, eh, ih, aw, uh, and five long-vowel sounds ay, ee, igh, oh, ue?
Or something else? What do you think a vowel is?

A vowel is simply a sound that you can 'sing' with your mouth open for a few seconds.
For example, 'pet' has three sounds p eh t, but you can only sing the eh. You can only hold the m in 'mat' or the n' in 'nod' if you close your mouth.
On the 'WORDS' tab are a few words. Try to 'sing' their sounds and confirm that vowels are different from other sounds.

If you play with sounds for a few minutes, you will see that you can hold r, wh, v and j. Those are sometimes called semi-vowels and behave like vowels in many ways. Try them.
So again, how many vowels are there? We are going to teach the 16 vowels across the top of this page, but there is no clear answer. Depending on who is counting and why, there are between 14 and 20 vowels in English, plus the semi-vowels.
Identify the part of the word that you can 'sing' with your                                mouth open.  It is the vowel.

The next tab of this lesson lists 16 vowels we will study in this program, with an example word below. We would like you and your tutor to memorize the sounds of the vowels (don't bother remembering the example words).
The sound ah makes an 'ahh' sound like 'cat'. We want you to see ah and say 'ahh'.
You can practice them on tab 3 without the example words. Then visit the Words page and make sure you know them.

Read the word AND the vowel sound, for example: 'CAR' - ar
'BUG' - uh
and then find them in the vowel list at the top of the page.

You may notice that some vowels include the letter 'r', such as air, ar, and er. That is because they are a single sound, you can 'sing' them with the 'r' and you cannot split them up.
Some lists of phoneme vowels include ire, ore, ear, and other r-sounds. We leave them out because they can usually be split into two sounds. Consider 'fire', do you say it in one syllable or two? If you say it as one syllable, can you still sing the igh and then add the r?
Now try that with 'fair' or 'farm' or 'fort'. Not as easy.

In the 'ire' words, the vowel is igh, and the 'r' is a separate sound. You can see that by comparing them to the second word in the pair. Check them out.

Think about the ire words like 'fire', do you pronounce them with ONE syllable or TWO? Try it both ways.
Compare the 'a_e' words (vowel is ay) to the air words (vowel is air). The 'r' controls the spelling and changes the sound.

The first Bossy R spelling we will learn is er. er is usually found at the end of words like in the word mother, but it can also be found in the middle of words like in the word serve.
Bossy r is bossy but polite. It lets the vowel go first, but it does not let it say its sound. For example in the word her, you do not hear the vowel sound e, only the consonant sound of r.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The sound oh has four common spellings:
  • o_e as in 'note'
  • o as in 'most'
  • oa as in 'goat'
  • ow as in 'grow'
It also has less-common spellings, including:
  • oe as in 'toe'
  • ough as in 'though'
  • ou as in 'soul'
  • oo as in 'door'
Note: we treat or as oh+r as in pore, pour, more, door, snore, store.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The sound ow has two common spellings:
  • ow as in 'cow'
  • ou as in 'loud'
It also has a less-common spellings:
  • ough as in 'drought'
  • o as in 'sour'
Note: Some phonics programs treat our as a sound, and we don't. We think 'hour' and 'sour' are multi-syllable words. There are only a half-dozen them, and there is no harm if you consider them to share the ou of 'loud'. We think looks like this:
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.
There is no rule or logic to some of these                                    spellings.  All that is required is for your                                    student to be aware of them.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The sound oy has two common spellings:
  • oy as in 'boy'
  • oi as in 'coin'
It also has some rare spellings which we will ignore:
  • aw as in 'lawyer'
  • uoy as in 'buoy'
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.
Be very strict about sounding these pairs out.  Make                                    sure your student hears and announces the differences.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The spelling pattern oo has two sounds: long oo as in spoon, and short oo as in book. This lesson will focus on the long oo sound. The long oo sound has five common spellings:
  • oo as in 'spoon'
  • ue as in 'blue'
  • ew as in 'crew'
  • ou as in 'you'
  • ui as in 'fruit'
  • o-e as in 'lose'
  • u-e as in 'flute'
    • It also has some rare spellings:
  • o as in 'to'
  • wo as in 'two'
  • oe as in 'shoe'
  • u as in 'feud'
  • au as in 'beauty'
  • ough as in 'through'
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The spelling pattern oo has two sounds: long oo as in spoon, and short oo as in book. This lesson will focus on the short oo sound.The short oo sound has two common spellings:
  • oo as in 'book'
  • u as in 'bull'
It also has two rare spellings:
  • ou as in 'could'
  • o as in 'woman'
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.
Be very strict about sounding these pairs out.  Make                                    sure your student hears and announces the differences.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The sound aw has four common spellings:
  • o as in 'dog'
  • a as in 'swan'
  • au as in 'launch'
  • aw as in 'law'
It also has some infrequent spellings:
  • augh as in 'caught'
  • ough as in 'ought'
  • oa as in 'broad'
And only one word with this spelling: awe as in 'Awe'.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The sound ay can be made with several different letter combinations:
  • ai as in 'train'
  • ay as in 'say'
  • a as in 'angel'
  • a-e as in 'cake'
  • ea as in 'break'
  • ey as in 'grey'
  • eigh as in 'eight'
  • ei as in 'veil'
  • aigh as in 'straight'
    • It also has some infrequent spellings:
  • et as in 'ballet'
  • e-e as in 'suede'
  • ae as in 'sundae'
    • In this lesson we will focus on the more common spellings.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The sound air has several spellings. The most common are listed below:
  • are as in 'care'
  • air as in 'fair'
  • ere as in 'where'
  • ear as in 'bear'
  • eir as in 'their'
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The ee sound can be be made by 13 different letter combinations.
  • ee as in 'bee'
  • e as in 'me'
  • ea as in 'seat'
  • y as in 'puppy'
  • ey as in 'monkey'
  • ie as in 'brief'
  • e_e as in 'theme'
  • ei as in 'ceiling'
  • i as in 'physique'
  • i_e as in 'sardine'
  • eo as in 'people'
  • is as in 'debris'
  • oe as in 'phoenix'
This lesson will cover the ee and -e spellings.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The ee sound can be be made by 13 different letter combinations. This lesson will cover ea as in seat.
Most often the spelling pattern ea has the long vowel sound as in teacher.In a later lesson we will learn ea with the short vowel sound as in head.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.
The ee sound often comes at the end of a word. This lesson will cover y as in baby, ie as in cookie and ey as in monkey.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.
The ee sound can be represented with 13 different letter combinations. This lesson will cover ie as in brief and the less common ei as in receive.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.
Read down or across. Notice the first column is pronounced with the ee sound and the second column is pronounced with the eh sound.
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.

The sound igh has several spellings. :
  • i-e as in 'kite'
  • igh as in 'high'
  • y as in 'sky'
  • ie as in 'tie'
  • i as in 'item'
Practice reading these words. Then turn the screen away and have your student write some of them down.
